FIFTY YEARS AGO.

I landed in Saskatchewan the Spring of 85,
And at this writing you will know that I am still alive
Those were the good old balmy days, when men were men I trow,
But things are not the same today, as fifty Years ago.
Those were the days the C.P.R.,
Linked up with bands of steel,
This great Dominion Canada.
For all the public weal,
The men that dominated at that time
Did plainly show,
That they were equal to their task
Some fifty Years ago.
They had no time to waste on golf,
Their vision reached the skies,
They never shirked their duty
Till their dream did realize,
Their names are written in the page
Of history to show,
They had the brain and grit to do,
Some fifty Years ago.
To those who followed after,
The idle cultured rich,
Have thrown this monument they built
Completely in the ditch,
With stream line cars, and ne'er a care,
They wander to and fro,
Compare these men to those who lived
Some fifty Years ago.
Tis said the World's progressing
I'll leave that up to you,
I'll make one guess, it's simple,
Our system's almost thru,
Injections do not seem to help
The Patient's down too low,
The vigor, health, and all is gone,
Since fifty Years ago.
The systematic robbing
Of timber, mine and soil,
Assisted by big business
Who grabs off all the spoil,
The millions going on relief,
The mortgaged homes all show
The govts', have lost control
Since fifty Years ago.
But never mind, Election time
Is not so far away,
It matters not which way you vote
You'll still be making hay,
To some it means a job of course
The others pass below, to join their friends & neighbors

Kind Friend:-

It seems strange that after living in Sask., for last sixty seven Years, I find we have had "Saskatchewan History" published has been published during the past seven Years, and would like to have a copy, (back Number), preparatory to sending my subscription.

I arrived in N.W.T. then, now Sask. in Nov. 1887, and am at present writing my life in Sask. since then, and am at present writing my story to the Jubilee contest for short story, and am busy at it now.

My education ended at age of twelve Years, as there was no school then.

We settled one Mile from where Saltcoats is now located. God willing, I hope to celebrate my eightieth birthday on 18th July 1955.

I started to write a little poetry, after I was sixty five Years of age, and enclose one or two.

Sincerely yours,

W.S. Ratcliff

SOUVENIRS.

Old faded ink spotted school books,
Worn out little old shoes,
Love letters tied with pink ribbon,
Churches with old fashioned pews,
Old fashioned photos in tin type,
Old swimming holes neath the willows,
Old Mothers who bade us adieu.

Don't worry about the Future,
It doesn't belong to you,
Today will decide your tomorrow,
Play fair, and good will accrue.

Every day is a fresh beginning,
Every Morn is a World made new,
Are we planning, or simply drifting?,
The question is up to you.

Tis not the fear of Death that counts,
For Death is akin to birth,
Tis the interim poised between the two,
That proves our honest worth.

You may purchase a dog, including his wail,
But you can't buy his love, or the wag of his tail.

Live such a life that when you die,
The undertaker too, will cry.

S.Rattray.

Preseeville, Sask.
Jan. 12th./55.

The Canadian Indian.

He raise no monument to him, who's past
Fades like a dream at break of day,
No crown or token was there ever cast
To mark him, as a Nation pass'd away.

He knew naught of the God that we proclaim,
He lived with Nature, and he knew her best,
His heart was pure, his mind was ever sane,
He slept in peace on Nature's flowing breast.

The powers who suppressed his simple sway,
And now control his land of Native birth,
May yet admit the folly of their way,
Are we, I ask, the equal of his worth.

His nation was not built in terms of gold,
Alto he held the secrets of the soil,
But intuition taught him to withhold,
And live his life without incessant toil.

He had no jail in which to harbour crime,
He met Death face to face without a fear,
His courage and his patience was sublime,
His morals stern, but sharper yet his spear.

Who is our God, and what our special creed?
That gave us power, their numbers to outweigh,
His day is done, and most his noble seed,
Are passing toward the sunset of his day.

It was no war that laid this nation low,
He met his foes, he knew naught of the pen,
He gave his pledge, as long as Rivers flow,
That held forever be the friend of man.

He kept his pledge thru-out the storry past,
His honour is maintained until this day,
And all that now reminds us of his past,
Is broken arrows, bits of potted play.

S. Rattray.

I arrived Saskatchewan,
Ninth seventy years ago,
I've travelled over Canada,
Thru Summer heat, and snow,
I've worked in lumber camps, and mines,
I've salled the Salty Sea,
But now I'm heading home again
Saskatchewan for me.

I'll see the homestead once again,
Meet Mother at the door,
The Meadow Lark will greet me
As in the days of yore,
'Tis then I'll settle down for life,
Among friends who've stood the test,
My roaming days are over,
Saskatchewan is best.

I see the fields of wheat grain
The castle in the sun,
A Tiger Lily here and there,
Nodding in the sun,
My heart is filled with rapture
As my prairie home I scan,
The breaks are set, the train has stopped
Back home Saskatchewan.

Rattray.

Rattray.
There was a time not so long ago
Some people will recall,
When you could take your sweetest girl
To any big-time Ball,
A dollar bill would pay the shot
Today it costs you ten,
The timing of your girl
Is, have you got the yen.

With all the style, and Clash,
You can't hang rails around the wheel,
Like you could around the dash,
Old Bobbin understood the Game
For he'd been there before,
And many were the happy Nieces,
Back in the days of yore.

So if you're Planning married Life,
Don't rush the Game too Fast,
Be sure you have the capital
To make the Union Last,
Conditions as we see today,
May land you on the rocks
With nothing Left to comfort you
Except your worn out Socks.

S. Rattey.
Buggy Days.

There was a time not so long ago
Some people will recall,
When you could take your sweetest girl
To any big-time ball; would pay the shot.
A dollar bill would cost you ten,
Today it costs you yen,
The winning of your girl.
Is, have you got the yen?

The happy buggy days are gone
With all the style and flash,
You can't hang reins around the wheel,
Like you could around the dash,
Old Dobbin understood the game,
For he'd been there before,
And many were the happy days,
Back in the days of yore.

So if you're planning married life,
Don't rush the game too fast,
Be sure you have the capital,
To make the Union last,
Conditions as we see today,
May land you on the rocks,
With nothing left to comfort you,
Except your worn out socks.

S. Rattray.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Wellwood Scott Rattray  
2. Your address: Prescotille, Sask.  
3. Date: March 18th, 1925  
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) I was born at Papua City, Canada, this is on the River Clyde. I was 12 Years of age when we arrived in Canada, the last ship the Beesops Arrived, to sail for Canada that year.  
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Chas. Rattray, farming, ranching, in Sask., from 1887 till retirement.  
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) 1887, Nov.  
7. Mention any other places where you have lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Glasgow, Scotland. Later at Gourrock from where we left for Canada, this is on the River Clyde. I was 12 Years of age when we arrived in Canada, the last ship the Beesops Arrived, to sail for Canada that year.  
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age and that was the end of my life.)  
9. What were your reasons for coming West? I came to Canada, but I remember very well, nine are living today, and three of them, finally there were ten children.  
10. How did you learn about the West? Through other people? Reading about it? As he had been learning in school in Gourrock of the rebellion in 1885, so thought we might all be spared, but on I worked for the Peter Indian Dept., stationed in Kansas in 1901 for three years, and found the Indians very friendly, as were the settlers. Mr. Churchill and myself, but were instructed, under the direction of Mr. Graham, tried to get us to go and help him, but he was too busy with his work, but he brought me here, and I will let him bring it down to earth. The work which Mr. Metre has proved so successful, in the Great Canadian Council of the Brothers together. Our own type of honoring the greatest Nation on Earth, providing we have the vision, Canada is a real Country, but let us be careful, quit, as this is not what you asked for.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Eastern Canada? Hard to answer at my age, but I did look forward to the chance. A child looks at Christmas, and I have never been disappointed.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? With my parents, father, mother, myself, and two sisters.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Left Glasgow Oct. 31st, 1887, and arrived in Quebec Nov. 4th, 1887, and remained there until Dec. 15th, 1887. We had a hard time getting started because we had no horses or oxen. We traveled with dogs and sledges. We loaded our things onto sledges and traveled through the woods. We encountered many difficulties along the way, including snowstorms and difficult terrain.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? People or other experiences. We encountered many difficulties along the way, including snowstorms and difficult terrain.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? On the homestead at where all tenets now live, there was no store, no school, no doctor, and very few people. It was very difficult to survive.

16. Have you visited any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Eastern Canada? I worked as a laborer on a farm for six months. This was in 1885.

19. How did you earn a living after coming to Eastern Canada? I worked as a laborer on a farm for six months. This was in 1885.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
Dad and Mother wrote to friends in Glasgow, Gourrock, and Manchester where Mother's family lived.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I was married near Buchanan where my Wife's Father, lived, to be exact, Devils Lake, then designed as N.W.Territories in 1901, on 26th day of November. We have three children, all in Canada, and doing O.K.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? Not that I am aware of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
There was Dad, Mother, and myself, and two Sisters, lived at Saltcoats, the family increased to seven girls in a row, and two boys, ten in all, and all alive and doing as well as present conditions will permit, and I mentioned before, some 200 descendants. We are arranging a family tree now.
Two of my Sisters are retired, and living in Yorkton, Sask.
One in Carstairs Alta., One in B.C., One in Humboldt, Sask., One at Foam Lake, and one met with an accident in running a team of horses, which resulted in her death.
One brother at Govan, Sask., and the youngest brother near Demolines U.S.A.
Father and Mother died at 82 and 79 respectively; I am nearing 77, and thank God, able to work and still get a kick out of life.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? The second Year in Sask., 1888, we were used to using shorts, but they were shorts then, and we lived most of the Winter on shorted bread, scones, bread, with plenty of good rich pure milk, and were very much healthier, and not ashamed to tell it, had plenty of vegetables etc., and built up a foundation which proves that the food in those days was pure, which cannot be said of most of the so-called food we get today.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
We did not travel far in those early days, but our friends and neighbours might live 50 to 100 miles distant, but we knew about them, and they were the means of travel later horses, light bronchos from U.S. which we had to break in, and it was fun.
The only form of recreation was a dance among the neighbours, when we would put some hay in the waggon box, pile in, dance till dark, have breakfast, come home do the chores, and have a sleep, we had to make our own fun. Never heard of drinking anything stronger than water or milk, can't say that today.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
Dad and Mother wrote to friends in Glasgow, Gourrock, and Manchester where Mother's family lived.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I was married near Buchanan where my wife's Father lived, to be exact, Devils Lake, then designed as N.W.Territorial, in 1901, on 25th day of November. We have three children, all in Canada, and doing O.K.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? Not that I am aware of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
There was Dad, Mother, and myself, and two Sisters, lived at Saltcoats, the family increased to seven girls in a row, and two boys, ten in all, and all alive and doing as well as present conditions will permit, and I mentioned before, some 200 descendants. We are arranging a family tree now.
Two of my Sisters are retired, and living in Yorkton, Sask.
One in Carstairs Alta., One in B.C., One at Humbolt, Sask., One at Foam Lake, and one met with an accident in runaway team of horses, which resulted in her death.
One brother at Uxbridge, Sask., and the youngest brother near Demolino U.S.A.
And Father and Mother died at 62, and respectively, I am nearing 77, and thank God, able to work and still get a kick out of life.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? The second Year in Sask., 1888, we were used to using oxen, but they were shorts then, and we lived most of the Winter on short as porridge, scones, bread, with plenty of good rich pure milk, and were never more healthy, and not ashamed to tell it, had plenty of vegetables etc., and built up a foundation which proves that the food in those days was pure, which cannot be said of most of the so-called food we get today.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
We did not travel far in those early days, but our friends and neighbours might live 50 to 100 miles distant, but we knew about them, and even were by means of travel later horses, light broughams from U.S. which we had to break in, and it was fun.
The only form of recreation was a dance among the neighbours when we would put some hay in the waggon box, pile in, dance till daylight, have breakfast, come home do the chores, and have a sleep, we had to make our own fun. Never heard of drinking anything stronger than water or milk, can't say that today.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving? Did many return?

Some people in Southern part of Sask. did move, but very few as compared to those who moved North to share the rain-fall land and new surroundings were much preferred to the soil desert conditions in Southern part of the province, but with the advent of the proposed dam on S.Saskatchewan River, these conditions will be changed and will add to the comfort and well being of the people who have remained.

And we hope the work will soon commence on the project. If the Federal Govt. does not care to assist in this undertaking, we can do it ourselves, we are on the verge of great prosperity in this province.

The first school built in the district was called "First School," District No. 1, H.C. This would be about 1871.

The first crop of 20 acres was cut with an old mower in 1871.

There were no lodges of any kind in the district until 1900 when the Independent Order of Odd Fellows was organized.
